children.value:
, I used GTSAM for object pose
estimation and 3D reconstruction of hand joints to study hand-object interaction.
I love GTSAM for its ability to optimize geometric quantities and deal with
uncertainty in observations. However, it is easy to get lost in the web of
inverse transformations while optimizing complex geometric systems. I’ve found
that naming code variables consistently with textbook notation conventions can
help mitigate this. This post describes some suggestions for doing that.
Always name your 3D points like how you would on paper. A point

children.html: cX^{c}XcX
ccc

children.value: 3D points use uppercase letters, 2D points use lowercase letters.

Name your pose variables like how you would write them on paper.
The pose

children.html: wTc^wT_cwTc​
ccc
www
oTc= oTw ⋅ wTc^oT_c =~^oT_w~\cdot~^wT_coTc​= oTw​ ⋅ wTc​

children.value:
Point3 wX = wTc.transformFrom(cX);
// same as Point3 wX = wTc * cX;
This operation uses the inverse of the camera pose

cX~= (wTc)−1 ⋅ wX~^c\tilde{\mathbf{X}} =~\left(^wT_c\right)^{-1}~\cdot~^w\tilde{\mathbf{X}}cX~= (wTc​)−1 ⋅ wX~

children.value:
to transform 3D points into the camera
coordinates, so you should use the pose of the camera w.r.t. world while
constructing the object:

Pose3 wTc = Pose3(...);
SimpleCamera cam(wTc, K);

for example. Other factors
like the

children.html: sensorX~= sensorTworld ⋅ worldX~= sensorTbody ⋅ bodyTworld ⋅ worldX~=(worldTbody ⋅ bodyTsensor)−1 ⋅ worldX~\begin{align*} ^{sensor}\tilde{\mathbf{X}} &=~^{sensor}T_{world}~\cdot~^{world}\tilde{\mathbf{X}}\\ &=~^{sensor}T_{body}~\cdot~^{body}T_{world}~\cdot~^{world}\tilde{\mathbf{X}}\\ &= \left(^{world}T_{body}~\cdot~^{body}T_{sensor}\right)^{-1}~\cdot~^{world}\tilde{\mathbf{X}} \end{align*}sensorX~​= sensorTworld​ ⋅ worldX~= sensorTbody​ ⋅ bodyTworld​ ⋅ worldX~=(worldTbody​ ⋅ bodyTsensor​)−1 ⋅ worldX~​

children.value:
: In a mobile robot SLAM scenario, wheel odometry might tell you where
the robot body is in the world (

children.html: worldTbody^{world}T_{body}worldTbody​

children.value:
), and the robot URDF spec
might tell you where the camera is on the robot body (

children.html: bodyTsensor^{body}T_{sensor}bodyTsensor​

children.value: It will project the world 3D point

children.html: worldX~^{world}\tilde{\mathbf{X}}worldX~

children.value: into the sensor coordinates like so:

Pose3 world_T_sensor = world_T_body * body_T_sensor;
Point3 sensor_X = world_T_sensor.transformTo(world_X);
and then project it to the image using instrinsics and then compare it to the detection
